title: 107_hr4963
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cancer Survivorship Research and Quality of Life Act of 2002". The Congress finds that there are over 9,000,000 cancer survivors in the US, with 60% being 65 years or older. Additionally, 62% of adults diagnosed with cancer today will live 5 years from now. In 2002, 555,500 Americans will die of cancer, costing $180 billion annually. In fiscal year 2001, the National Institutes of Health invested $38 million in survivorship, which amounts to less than $4.25 per survivor. SEC. 3 amends the Public Health Service Act to include survivorship in cancer control programs. SEC. 4 expands and coordinates NIH activities for cancer survivorship research. The Director of NIH will expand and coordinate activities for cancer survivorship research. An Office on Survivorship will be established within the Institute to implement and direct these activities. An Associate Director for Survivorship will be appointed to coordinate programs related to cancer survivorship research. The Associate Director for Survivorship, appointed by the Director of the Institute, will prepare a report on survivorship activities and strategies for future activities. Funding for the Office on Survivorship will receive 13 percent for fiscal year 2003 and subsequent years, with at least 3 percent allocated specifically for the Office on Survivorship. Expansion of CDC comprehensive cancer programs to improve cancer survivorship. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the CDC, will study health challenges of cancer survivorship and implement projects to enhance survivors' long-term health. This includes expanding surveillance systems, assessing survivorship challenges, and developing a national action plan in collaboration with health organizations. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will develop innovative programs to support cancer survivorship, including promoting physical activity, providing educational outreach for healthcare providers, improving quality of life for survivors, implementing home and community-based interventions, offering peer support programs, conducting public awareness campaigns, and disseminating information on survivorship programs. The Secretary will develop unique cancer survivorship programs for underserved populations, coordinate activities with other Public Health Service agencies, submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2003, and authorize $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2003 with additional funding for 2004 through 2006. SEC. 399E-1. MONITORING AND EVALUATING QUALITY CANCER CARE AND CANCER SURVIVORSHIP. This section amends Part M of title III of the Public Health Service Act to focus on monitoring and evaluating quality cancer care and survivorship. The Secretary will make grants to eligible entities to monitor and evaluate quality cancer care, develop information, and monitor cancer survivorship. Eligible entities must operate a statewide cancer registry and be certified by a recognized organization. Grants can be used to contract with academic institutions and other entities. Grants can only be made if an application is submitted to the Secretary. The Secretary will make grants to eligible entities for quality cancer care monitoring, information development, and survivorship monitoring. Grants require an application to be submitted and must be used as determined by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. A conforming amendment is made regarding authorization of appropriations under the Public Health Service Act.
